initial_story:
Firefighters and police were seen outside the office of Mike Freer MP

Police are investigating a suspected arson attack at the office of North London Conservative MP Mike Freer.

A fire broke out at the rear of the North Finchley and Golders Green MP's constituency office at around 19:00 on Christmas Eve.

The Met Police confirmed it is investigating the fire.

Mr Freer told the BBC the fire happened at the rear of the premises and no one was in the building at the time of the incident.

He continued: "The police and fire brigade were on the scene in minutes and have been incredible in their response."

London Fire Brigade (LFB) confirmed the fire started in a shed outside the office before spreading to the rest of the building.

An LFB spokesperson said: "An external shed was destroyed by fire. Part of the first, second and third floors of the property were also damaged by the blaze."

In a statement, a Metropolitan Police spokesperson said: "The cause of the fire is under investigation as it is believed it may have been started deliberately. There have been no arrests."

Pictures posted on social media showed Metropolitan Police and LFB vehicles at the premises on Sunday evening.

Mr Freer has represented the North London constituency since 2010.

He is parliamentary under-secretary of state for courts and legal services, a junior role in the Ministry of Justice.

Pictures show the fire spread to an office inside the building
stories: Detectives and forensic experts swarmed the local campaign headquarters of Councilwoman Maria Rodriguez, a rising star in the city's Democratic party. A mysterious blaze had engulfed the building's storage room, reducing it to ashes and damaging the adjacent offices. The fire department responded quickly, containing the flames before they could spread further. Councilwoman Rodriguez, who was not present at the time of the incident, praised the swift response of the emergency services. "I'm grateful no one was hurt, and I'm confident the authorities will get to the bottom of this," she said. The police have launched an investigation, suspecting arson due to the unusual nature of the fire. As they sift through the charred remains, they're reviewing security footage and interviewing potential witnesses. The motive behind the attack remains unclear, but speculation is rife in the close-knit political community. Councilwoman Rodriguez, known for her progressive stance on social justice issues, has faced opposition from some quarters, but few expected it to escalate to this level. The incident has sent shockwaves through the city's political establishment, with many calling for calm and unity in the face of this senseless act of violence.

In the quiet hours of dawn, a sinister silence fell over the renowned Azure Gallery, a hub for avant-garde artists in the city's vibrant cultural scene. A deliberate act of vandalism had ravaged the studio of rising star, painter Maya Singh, leaving a trail of shattered canvases and splintered easels. The police responded promptly, securing the crime scene and launching an investigation into the targeted attack. Maya Singh, shaken but unharmed, vowed to continue her provocative work, undeterred by the intimidation. "Art should never be silenced," she declared. As detectives pored over security footage and eyewitness accounts, suspicion fell on a rival artist, known for his ruthless ambition. The motive behind the destruction remained unclear, but the art community was abuzz with speculation, divided between those who saw it as a heinous attack on creative freedom and others who whispered of a desperate cry for attention. The incident sent ripples through the city's cultural elite, prompting calls for solidarity and a renewed commitment to artistic expression in the face of adversity.
